intro: Silene otites var. trichocalycina, commonly known as the woolly catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which give it a distinctive, fuzzy appearance. The plant produces clusters of small, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands. Silene otites var. trichocalycina is adapted to arid conditions and has a long blooming period, making it a notable species in its native range.
